answers.answer: I DON'T REALLY KNOW MUCH ABOUT THIS BUT I HAVE A FRIEND WHOSE SISTER HAD LUPUS AND SHORTLY AFTER GIVING BIRTH MAYBE 1YR SHE PASSED AWAY. NOT TO DISCOURAGE YOU. MY FRIEND'S SISTER DIDN'T KNOW THAT SHE ACTUALLY HAD LUPUS UNTIL SHE GOT PREGO, IF THAT HELPS YOU OUT. I WILL TRULY KEEP YOU IN MY PRAYERS. I HAVE DIABETES (TYPE 1) I MISCARRIED ON MAY 22 SO I KNOW THE CONCERNS YOU MAY BE HAVING

Did your doctor ever mention anything to you about Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS)?  I also have a positive ANA and have no symptoms of Lupus whatsoever but this APS was mentioned to me.  To make a long story short, it's known as "sticky blood."  It just means that the blood clots too easily.  One of the major problems with APS is miscarriages.  Don't let that discourage you though because there are ways of having a successful pregnancy.  I myself have no children yet but want to start trying within the next year and I take one baby aspirin per day to help the clotting.  I am also not allowed to be on b/c pills because it causes blood clots.  I looked up APS on the internet and didn't find much....I would mention it to your doctor and possibly see a rheumatologist.  Good luck to you.....

question: Hi All,Some of you may recognize the name, but to be brief, I miscarried last week at 7 weeks.I have a question, I am ANA positive which is a strong sign of Lupus, however, I technically do not have Lupus because I don't have ALL the symptoms.  My ANA Positive result was low, but nonetheless still positive.  My regular OB totally dismissed it, but I've done some reading and it looks like regardless is you have a low positive or not, your pregnancy becomes High Risk immediately.  My question is, does anyone have anymore information on ANA Positive and Pregnancies?
title: Anyone know anything about ANA positive?
